items.name: Turkey Tail
items.description: The Turkey Tail (Trametes versicolor), also called Many-Colored Polypore, is one of the most common and medically significant polypores worldwide. The fan to rosette-shaped fruiting body shows characteristic concentric color zones in gray, brown, blue and green tones. As a white rot fungus, it decomposes dead wood of deciduous trees. It is the source of PSK (Krestin) and PSP, which are used as approved cancer medicines in Asia and stimulate the immune system.

ecology.trophic_notes: Primarily a white rot fungus that degrades lignin in deadwood. Can also attack weakened living trees.
ecology.guild_evidence: Fruiting bodies grow exclusively on wood, enzymatic studies confirm lignin degradation

quick_id_checklist.label: Concentric, multicolored zones on upper surface
White to cream-colored pores on underside
Growing on deadwood of deciduous trees

confusion_consequences.beschreibung: Have smooth underside instead of pores - not poisonous but without medicinal value
Similar but less colorful - also not poisonous

key_differentiating_features: Concentric, multicolored zones (gray, brown, blue, green)
White to cream-colored pores (3-5 per mm)
identification.primary_structure_surface: Velvety to finely felty, with concentric zones
identification.primary_structure_color: Multicolored: gray, brown, blue, green, white in zones
identification.taste_description: Mild, leathery, tough (not suitable for eating)

medicine.description: Turkey Tail is one of the best-researched medicinal mushrooms. The polysaccharides PSK (Krestin) and PSP derived from it are approved cancer medicines in Asia.

traditional_medicine.historical_use: Used in TCM for centuries as a tonic and to strengthen the immune system. In Japan, PSK was approved in 1977 as the first mushroom-based cancer medicine.

clinical_studies: Numerous RCTs in Japan and China on PSK/PSP for cancer
Phase I studies on immune stimulation in breast cancer
Studies on improved survival rates in gastric and colorectal cancer
meta_analyses: Cochrane Reviews on PSK for gastric cancer show significant benefits
medicine.dosage_notes: PSK is typically administered at 3 g/day orally. Extracts and powders vary by manufacturer.

dosage_schemes.notes: PSK standard dose in clinical studies

origin_wild_collection.sustainability_concerns: Common mushroom, no concerns with moderate collection

origin_cultivation.methods: Substrate cultivation on sawdust or wood

medicine.quality_differences: Extracts vary greatly in polysaccharide content. Beta-glucan content should be standardized.
medicine.patient_information: Trametes versicolor is a well-tolerated medicinal mushroom with strong research basis for immune stimulation. Approved in Asia as adjuvant for cancer therapy.
medicine.for_physicians: PSK and PSP are the clinically best-studied mushroom polysaccharides. Randomized studies show improved survival rates in gastric and colorectal cancer in combination with chemotherapy.

further_literature.title: Trametes versicolor Mushroom Immune Therapy in Breast Cancer
further_literature.journal: Journal of the Society for Integrative Oncology

medicine.profile: Immunomodulator with strong clinical evidence as adjuvant in cancer therapy

safety.safety_edibility_notes: Not poisonous, but not suitable as an edible mushroom due to its tough-leathery consistency. Used exclusively medicinally as tea or extract.
safety.safety_warning_text: Not poisonous, but not usable as an edible mushroom. For medicinal use: Use quality-controlled products. For immunosuppressed persons or before surgery, consult a physician.
safety.safety_summary: Non-toxic medicinal mushroom. Tough-leathery consistency makes it unsuitable as an edible mushroom. Widespread and medically significant.
safety_contraindications: Severe autoimmune diseases without medical supervision
safety_id_requirements: Concentric color zones on upper surface
White pores on underside (3-5 per mm)
safety.confusion_similarity_details: Similar polypores either have no pores (Stereum) or are differently colored/structured. No toxic lookalikes.
confusion_key_features: T. versicolor: Velvety surface, colorful zones
T. versicolor: White pores 3-5 per mm
T. hirsuta: Shaggy hairy, less colorful
safety.confusion_best_feature: Check pores - T. versicolor has fine white pores
safety.confusion_if_in_doubt: All similar species are non-toxic. If uncertain for medicinal use, rely on commercial products.
safety.recovery_prognosis: No poisoning risk. Rare allergic reactions subside quickly.

effect_profile.name: Dr. Leanna J. Standish
effect_profile.title: Bastyr University - Breast cancer immune therapy

clinical_studies.name: Dr. Leanna J. Standish
clinical_studies.title: Bastyr University - Phase I studies breast cancer

safety_edibility_status.name: Christopher Hobbs
safety_edibility_status.title: Medicinal Value of Turkey Tail Fungus (2004)

Taxonomy Genus
Trametes
Confusion Species List
  • Stereum hirsutum (Hairy Curtain Crust)
  • Stereum ostrea (False Turkey Tail)
  • Trichaptum biforme (Violet Toothed Polypore)
  • Trametes hirsuta (Hairy Bracket)
Confusion Consequences
low Stereum species
Have smooth underside instead of pores - not poisonous but without medicinal value
low Trametes hirsuta
Similar but less colorful - also not poisonous
low Trichaptum biforme
Has violet pores - not poisonous
Microscopy Key Features
  • Spores cylindrical, slightly curved
  • Spore size 5-6 x 1.5-2 um
  • Trametes-type hyphal structure

Patient Information
Trametes versicolor is a well-tolerated medicinal mushroom with strong research basis for immune stimulation. Approved in Asia as adjuvant for cancer therapy.
